nodes.text: A decision tree based machine learning model can classify and predict diabetes status from patient data
We used the Pima Indians Diabetes dataset of 768 patient instances with 9 attributes to develop and test the model
We implemented binary decision trees using Scikit-learn in Python (Spyder IDE) and visualized the resulting trees
Data preprocessing removed records with zero values in BloodPressure, BMI, and Glucose as presumed measurement errors
Tree splitting criteria and heterogeneity measures used include information gain (entropy), Gini index, and classification error for pruning
After removing records with zero BloodPressure, BMI, or Glucose there remained a cleaned dataset used for training and testing
The dataset was split into training and testing subsets in three experiments: 70/30, 50/50, and 30/70
Decision tree implementation used binary splits and standard heterogeneity measures to grow and visualize the classifier
Experiment 1: trained on 70% and tested on 30% produced the reported result figures and a visualized decision tree
Experiment 2: trained on 50% and tested on 50% produced results with accuracy 0.71 and an associated tree visualization
Experiment 3: trained on 30% and tested on 70% produced the reported result figures and a visualization
Evidence: the 50/50 split achieved the highest measured accuracy of 0.71 among tested splits
Conclusion: More allocated training data generally improves accuracy, but in these experiments the best measured accuracy occurred with a 50/50 split (accuracy 0.71)

Claim: Decision trees offer advantages for medical diagnosis including fast learning, rule generation, intuitive models, high prediction accuracy comparable to other methods, and nonparametric modeling
Limitation: The model output requires subsequent doctor consultation and more precise diagnosis; some dataset features may not be available to end users and could reduce system utility
